author: Deepa Soman
title: Shiva Rajkumar sir even prompted my dialogue
text:
Sanusha might still not have managed to shake off the "little girl" image in Mollywood but other film industries and their big stars seem to have noted the talented actress in her.
The State Award winner recently waltzed into Kannada film industry in style, starring as the heroine of none other than Shiva Rajkumar in Kabira .
Sanusha, who has almost wrapped up filming of the movie, shares her experiences in Sandalwood, the reasons for her choice of roles and more...
How did you get the role? Shiva Rajkumar sir's wife, Geetha ma'am, suggested my name to play this character. He had danced at an awards show in Malaysia a while ago and being blown away by the performance, I walked up to Geetha ma'am to appreciate it. She recognised me as the actress of the Tamil film Renigunta. Apparently, Kabira's team has been searching for a leading lady for this project for the past two years. Upon meeting me, she felt I would be apt for the role. It got me thrilled as the character is robust and the project is also strongâ€”script-wise and team-wise. It's a period film set in the 18th century and my character's name is Loyi.
What's your character Loyi like? The film's story is based on a play by B Hisham Sahni about Kabir Das. My character is a street sweet-seller girl, who is delightful and mature, and there is a beautiful love story between Kabira and Loyi. I mostly wear skirts and tops teamed with head scarves.
Tell us your experience on the film's set... For the first few days I was silent like never before in my life, as I didn't know to speak Kannada (laughs). Upon sensing that the crew is friendly and helpful, I started interacting, but they insisted I spoke Kannada and no other language. But the positive side was that I could ask anyone for help anytime and there were no restrictions on that. Now, I have picked up the language a bit, but lose the flow when I become conscious. There are a few offers to do more Kannada movies but I want to ensure that they are substantial roles and ones I am comfortable doing.
How was it working with Shiva Rajkumar? He is someone I admire, both as an actor and a person. I could see the amazing patience and professionalism in his work, especially during the filming of certain risky portions. There is a scene in which he is immersed into water, for which the shooting went on for quite a while, drowning and lifting him up from water numerous times. Despite being a tough scene, he kept giving the shots sans a body double until they got it right.
Without any starry airs, he even prompted dialogues for me while taking a difficult, emotional scene that serves as a turning point in the love story. The dialogue was quite long and at times I couldn't recollect some words, but it's his support that helped me do justice to the scenes.
In your recent Malayalam films like Nirnayakam, you weren't the lead but played a key role in the story, and it looks like you don't insist on being the heroine... It's about the impact a role has on the film and I don't believe in being part of a movie as a namesake leading lady, who appears in a lot of scenes with nothing much to do. While signing up for a film, I consider the team, strength of the story and my character's justification of being part of it. As an actor, I want to ensure that my role is pivotal to the story. In Nirnayakam, for instance, mine is a key character around which the film's message is built.
